Incorporating strength training exercises on land can help improve your swimming performance and reduce your risk of injury. Here are some exercises you can do on land to target your legs and glutes, which are essential for swimming:

**Leg Exercises:**

1. **Squats**: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, then bend your knees and lower your body until your thighs are parallel to the ground. Push back up to the starting position.
2. **Lunges**: Stand with your feet together, take a large step forward with one foot, and lower your body until your back knee almost touches the ground. Push back up to the starting position. Alternate legs.
3. **Leg Press**: Sit in a leg press machine with your feet shoulder-width apart on the platform. Push the platform away from you, extending your legs. Lower the platform back down to the starting position.
4. **Deadlifts**: Stand with your feet shoulder-width apart, bend down, and grab a weight or barbell with your hands shoulder-width apart. Lift the weight up to hip level, squeezing your glutes and pushing your hips back. Lower the weight back down to the starting position.
5. **Calf Raises**: Stand on a step or platform, raise up onto your tiptoes, and then lower back down.

**Glute Exercises:**

1. **Glute Bridges**: Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the ground. Lift your hips up towards the ceiling, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower your hips back down to the starting position.
2. **Hip Thrusts**: Sit on the edge of a bench or chair, place your hands next to your hips, and lift your hips up, squeezing your glutes at the top. Lower your hips back down to the starting position.
3. **Donkey Kicks**: Start on your hands and knees. Lift one leg up and back, keeping your knee bent at a 90-degree angle. Lower your leg back down to the starting position. Alternate legs.
4. **Side Lunges**: Stand with your feet together, take a large step to one side, and lower your body until your back knee almost touches the ground. Push back up to the starting position. Alternate legs.

**Tips and Variations:**

* Start with lighter weights and higher reps (12-15) to focus on endurance and muscle tone.
* Gradually increase the weight and lower the reps (8-10) to build strength and power.
* Incorporate explosive movements, such as jump squats or box jumps, to improve your power and speed.
* Focus on proper technique and engage your core muscles to maintain a stable body position.
* Incorporate exercises that target your core and upper body, such as planks, push-ups, and rows, to improve your overall swimming performance.

Remember to listen to your body and adjust the exercises and weights based on your fitness level and comfort. It's also essential to incorporate rest days and active recovery to allow your muscles to recover and rebuild.

By incorporating these exercises into your strength training routine, you'll be able to target your legs and glutes, improving your swimming performance and reducing your risk of injury. Happy training!
